titleStmt.author: Pecke, Thomas, b. 1637.
Martial.
More, Thomas, Sir, Saint, 1478-1535.
Cottrel, James, fl. 1649-1670.

publicationStmt.publisher: by James Cottrel, for Tho. Bassett in St. Dunstans CHurch yard in Fleet-street,

notesStmt.note: Martial's, More's, and Pecke's epigrams each have separate divisional title pages; pagination and register are continuous.

F.l. = Latin address the Bishop of Exeter, signed by Pecke; "The printer to the reader", (verse) signed: J.C. [i.e. James Cottrell]; an advertisement for Basset; a perpendicular half-title which reads: Peck's Epigrams; "Upon Cottrell, the printer" (verse, by Pecke), errata and "To the reader" (verse).

"When Pecke read Cottrell's verses, .. which ask the charity of the peruser for the errors in printing and claim the authorship of some of the contents, he was apparently sufficiently concerned to insist that Basset allow him to add a reply which in a few copies is found inserted in an unsigned leaf at the end"--Pforzheimer catalogue.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Parnaſsi Puerperium: OR, Some Well-wiſhes TO INGENUITY, IN THE Tranſlation of Six Hundred, of Owen's Epigrams; Martial de Spectaculis, or of Rarities to be ſeen in Rome; and the moſt Select, in Sir Tho. More. To which is annext A Century of Heroick Epigrams, (Sixty whereof concern the Twelve Caeſars; and the Forty remaining, ſeveral deſerving Perſons.) By the Author of that celebrated Elegie upon CLEEVELAND: THO. PECKE of the Inner Temple, Gent.

q.l: Iſta tamen mala ſunt. Quaſi nos manifeſta negemus:
Haec mala ſunt: ſed Tu, non Meliora facis.
My Stock of Wit is ſmall; let them who flout
My Poverty; be pleas'd, to bear Me out.

div.p: Printed at London by J. Cottrel, for Tho. Baſſett in St. Dunſtans Church-yard in Fleet-ſtreet, 1659.

div.head: To the Ingenious READERS.
div.p:
THat a Chain of Gold, could be faſtned to the Neck of a Flea; was heretofore ſuch a Rarity, that it obtain'd a Memorial in the Chronicle; and could not purchaſe Belief, at an eaſie Rate, untill it was rendred undeniable, by the verdict of Quotidian Experience. The facetious Epigrammatiſt, can boaſt a wit, capring hither, and as faſt retreating; conſcious of no greater Crime, then under
〈◊〉 fictitious Name, to Flea-bite ſome
particular Perſons: And draw • after it ſuch a Golden Chain of Invention, as challengeth not onely applauſe from the moſt Cynical Moroſity; but is irradiant with the two Poetical Jewels; Profit, and Pleaſure. In the Tranſlation of Owen, it was not neceſſary to be curious, in electing here and there an Epigram; by reaſon He carries an even ſtrain: and if I had omitted ſome in the firſt three Books; I could not have inſerted more ingenious. I made it my devoir to be Brief; Perſpicuous. And I hope from ſix hundred Penfulls of Ink, not many blots have fallen upon my Author. Out of
• artial, I ſelected his moſt Heroick
•• ok, of Rarities to be ſeen at
•• me. And becauſe Variety is delectable;
I have ſubjoyned fourty out of Sir Tho. More; And a Century of my Own. Although no part of Poetry, but is at my command: I have made choice of Epigrams, as the very Nerves of this exquiſite Art. For if a Poem be good, it conſiſts of nothing elſe, but various Epigrams; cemented by a dexterous ſagacity. And not onely Verſe, but Proſe, is dull, and languiſhing, unleſſe the ſparkling Genius of the Epigrammatiſt, be artificially interwoven. That Plaudit, the World were pleaſed to vouchſafe my Elegie, upon the unparalleld Poet Mr. Cleeveland; forbids me to complain of that carping humour, notoriouſly predominant in Engliſh men; in relation to any Authors of their own Countrey.
The candid acceptance granted me then, I have no reaſon to ſuſpect now; from ingenious, and deſerving Perſons of all ſorts. And as for a Generation of Scioliſts, that make it their recreation to ſlight others, either natural, or acquired endowments; I crave at their hands, to give the World as ample a Teſtimony of their abilities, as I have done of mine. And then if they think my Epigrams routed; I ſhall deſire them to trie their valour, upon my Satyrs.

div.head: Amico mihi magnopere colendo Juvenique tam propter morum ſuavitatem acutiſſimam ingenii indolem, & Proſapiae antiquiſſimae generoſitatem honorando Dom. THOMAE PECKO Armigero, &c.
In Poemata, &c.
div.l: QUis tua Maeonio roravit pectora ſucco
Peckiadum gentilis honos? Quae Muſa per auras
Enthea Sydereas Te ſuſtulit, alta ſonantem,
Atque inſpiratos afflavit Fulmine ſenſus?
Dum teneros Annos meditor, canumque cerebrum
Impubes mihi Neſtor eris, virtutibus annos
Qui ſuperas, calamoque ſenes, Sic gaudet Apollo
Imberbi comes ire Pater, dum ſpectat ephebum,
Et vix veſtitas roſea lanugine malas.
Quòd ſi ver tenerum tot jam produxit amoenos
Florum faſciculos, quae tum maturior aeſtas
Incrementa dabit, noſtroque obſonia ſeclo,
Et Naſcendorum Delectamenta Nepotum?
Scilicet auſpiciis primum foelicibus orſus
Cleevelando monumenta struis, Muſaque parentas
Manibus, altiſono gradiens ſuper aſtra Cothurno.
Nec veluti noſtri Juvenes, proh tempora! perdis
Creſcentes ſine fruge dies: Quodcunque ſopori
Temporis eximitur, studiis adjicitur, unde
Concoquis Authores, lectoſque in ſanguinis uſum
Et Succi convertis edax. Testabitur orbi
Illud opus ſapido, quantum praeceſſeris. Ipſe
Hiſtoricas, quantumque tumens Maeonidis aeſtro
Ebrius Aeonios dudum Potaveris amnes.

I decus Aeonidum, Famam
que extende per anglos
PECKE Tuos, ut Te felix Norfolcia natum
Vendicet, utque itidem te doctus Chamus alumnum
Jactet, uti patulus quandam diſcordibus orbis
Vocibus, Indigenae Cunas jactabat Homeri.

closer.signed: Haec in amicitia Teſſeram Profudit P. Piſcator.

div.head: 1. To the moſt Illuſtrious, the Lady Mary Nevill, my ever honoured Patroneſs.
div.l: I Want no Patrons, for to vouch my Books;
No places Rudeneſs, denies gracious Looks.
My Papers to the Reader, I ſhall vow;
The Dedication of my ſelf, take you.

div.head: 2. To the Reader.
div.l: IF you applaud what ever I have writ,
I muſt deride your Indigence of Wit:
If you praiſe nothing, (then the cauſe ſtands thus)
Your epithite ſhall be, The Envious.

div.head: 3. To Counſellor Hoskins concerning his Book.
div.l: THis Book is the Mad World; theſe verſes Men:
Chooſe Man or verſe; ſcarce one found good in ten.

div.head: 4. To the Lady Mary Nevill.
div.l: SUppoſe Pythagoras the white did kiſs,
When he talkt of a Metemſychoſis;
The proof is facile, that you are the ſame
with Pallas, Juno▪ and the Lemnian Dame.
For Three rich Vertues ſhine in you, alone;
When many Threes, cannot lay claim to One.

div.head: 5. To the ſame.
div.l: AS Phoebus revels in the arched skie,
And with him light, quarters her Majeſtie:
So ador'd Vertue proclaims it a Grace;
That ſhee's incumbent to your charming Face.
Whoever tell-tale Fame invites to ſee
Your Ladyſhip, bowes to captivity:
If he evade your Beauties Fetters; yet,
Inward endowments caſt a faithful Net.

div.head: 6. To her Ladyſhips Son, Mr. Tho. Nevill.
div.l: YOur Genius is ſo eminent, that due
Belief is baniſh't; though the ſtory's true.
He that will praiſe a Childe, doth Hope commend,
And not the Merits; which muſt crown the end:
Not Hope, but real Worth doth magnifie
The happy Torrent, of the Ingenie.

div.head: 7. To her Ladyſhips Daughter Caecilia.
div.l: THE Mother you are like: when I ſay this,
Avant as uſeleſs, all Periphraſis.

div.head: 8. Noſce teipſum, upon Harpalus.
div.l: TO ſome this (know your ſelf) were good advice;
But in the application, be you nice:
You are not worthy Knowledge; ſeek abroad,
Something that is, may once fall in thy road.

div.head: 9. To the Lawyer.
div.l: IF he be happy that can Cauſes ſcan,
You ken to plead our Cauſes: Oh brave Man!

div.head: 10. Ʋpon John Protus.
div.l: I Well remember Protus, you did threat,
That ſhortly, nothing ſhould your wedding let:
Your Latine phraſe, in my breſt creates ſtrife;
It ſignifies to Marry; Lead a wife.
VVhen Ale hath Crippled you, but in ſmall ſtead
You'l ſtand, your VVife, or any one to lead:
Nay, ſhun ſuch thoughts; and get a ſober Spouſe;
VVho in the dark may lead you; find your Houſe.

div.head: 11. Upon Aulus, an ignoble Nobleman.
div.l: FOR Honour (ſordid Aulus) which you ſhare,
To Predeceſſors, you indebted are.
But your baſe Spirit hath contriv'd to let
Poſterity, from living in your debt.

div.head: 12. Ʋpon Hernicus.
div.l: YOU Hernicus, did disburſe twenty pounds
To buy a Fool, what ſquander without bounds?
In time, thy laviſh Error, prethee ſee;
I would not give, ſuch a large Price for Thee.

div.head: 13. Venus.
div.l: SOwre is the Exit, though ſweet the addreſs,
Of the ſalacious Cyprian Empereſs.
She dreſſes up the firſt ſalutes with Joy;
Till the ſad parting proves her a Decoy.
So ſweet and dulcid Rivers, when they thruſt
Themſelves on Neptune, borrow ſalt diſguſt.

div.head: 14. To Doctor Gilbert.
div.l: YOu ſay the earth doth move; what wonders ſlip
From your ſage mouth! writ you this in a Ship?

div.head: 15. To the Phyſicians, and the Lawyers.
div.l: OUR Sickneſs is thy Health, O Galen: priſe
Our folly Plowden; for that makes ye wiſe.

div.head: 16. O Times! O Reformation!
div.l: REnowned Scaliger, in the worlds Eye,
Was the Refiner of Chronologie:
The ſhrivel'd Face of Time is waſht. The Man
That will correct the Manners; finde who can.

div.head: 17. The Judgment of Paris.
div.l: WHen Pallas, Juno, Venus, did refer
Their cauſe to Paris, choſe him Arbiter;
At firſt, his dazled eyes could not deſcry,
Which radiant Beauty, did the reſt outvy.
The Majeſty of Juno, yet at laſt,
And Pallas Wiſdom, miſt the winning-caſt.
The golden Apple's Venus Trophie. Love,
On earth is Victor; rules the Gods above.
Were Judgment now reverſt, the Golden Lump
Would win: and Juno Money turn up Trump.

div.head: 18. The German Truth.
div.l: MErry Democritus, affirm'd Truth did
In ſome deep Hogs-head (from Mens view) lie hid.
Grant but the Adage true, that Truth's in Wine;
Upſtarts the Dutch-man, and ſwears, Truth is mine.

div.head: 19. To Linus.
div.l: LInus hath his Study fill'd; but what then?
Not Books, but Bags, make the moſt learned Men.

div.head: 20. To a certain young Noble-man.
div.l: THat until hoary Hairs you ſpin out Breath,
All your acquaintance wiſh; but none your Death:
Conjoynt deſires, will afford a diſeaſe;
As for the Cure, to wiſh that none will pleaſe.

div.head: 21. To a certain poor Medic.
div.l: YOU who of late came to our City Poor,
Now cleanſe the pores; ('tis not as heretofore)
Phyſick you give the Sick; the ſick gives Gold:
You cure his New diſeaſe; and he, your Old.

div.head: 22. Ʋpon a certain Woman.
div.l: YOur Beauty begot Fame: but ſoon, alas,
The Mother, by the Daughter, murder'd was;
Whilſt a looſe Carriage, threw Ink on your Name;
And a good Face, was ſcratch'd, by a bad Fame.

div.head: 23. Ʋpon Marcus.
div.l: WHY durſt you offer Marcus to aver,
Nature abhorr'd a vacuum? confer
But with your empty skull; then you'l agree,
Nature will ſuffer a vacuitie.

div.head: 24. Ʋpon the Writers of our times. To the Reader.
div.l: WHether our Scriblers vent more Lies, would'ſt know,
In an Octavo, Quarto, Folio?
Thouſands of Lies are nothing; in an Age,
Time bound in the Decimo-ſexto Page:
If that the Sixteenth part, ſuch knacks can do;
What can a ſheet's, Gigantine Folio?

div.head: 25. Ʋpon Phyllis.
div.l: THE world can't bribe Phyllis to kiſs; But ſhe
Will receive millions; if they profer'd be:
For cunning tricks, pray let this Laſs alone;
Give, and Receive, ſhe underſtands all one.

div.head: 26. Ʋpon the ſame.
div.l: IF Love be fire, (as Proverbs talkt of old)
Accurſt am I! 'cauſe your fire burns ſo cold.

div.head: 27. The impious Atheiſt.
div.l: SNatch inſtant Time; uſe things whilſt in their prime;
The time wil be, when thou ſhalt have no Time.
Reſume let Grammar, Have been, Shall be; I,
To ſecure Is, will fix my induſtry.

div.head: 28. The Epitaph of the Atheiſt.
div.l: HE died, as if there were no Future ſtate;
And liv'd, as one invincible by fate.

div.head: 29. The Optative Mode.
div.l: THE Mode call'd Optative's the ſame welnigh,
With that Mode, couſin to Infinity:
Inſtance in thoſe, of moſt contented minde,
Yet ſuch, an end of wiſhing, ne'er could finde.

div.head: 30. Ʋpon Alanus.
div.l: ALL the day-long Alanus, now a wife;
Rails like a Bedlam, at a wedded life.
After ſo many brawlings; in the night,
They that think Marriage a fine thing, think right.

div.head: 31. Prophets, Poets.
div.l: THE Prophets predict true, what is to come:
Poets, in Fictions ſing, what hath been done.

div.head: 32. Upon Life, and Death.
div.l: LIfe hurries on to Death; the foaming floud
Of Neptune, ſo, is Rivers period:
We ruminate on Life, as a ſweet notion;
But to all taſtes, Death is a bitter portion.

div.head: 33. Of Vulcan.
div.l: MOſt glorious armour, was by Vulcan made,
For the fierce god of war; Mars drives a trade,
And gives him no leſs famous horns: How now,
Take Horns for Steel? not ſuch a fool, I trow.

div.head: 34. The Grammar in Engliſh.
div.l: THings only proper unto Males;
The Female Sex claim, as their Vales.

div.head: 35. Free Will.
div.l: FRee Will, the nurſe of ſublunary Strife;
A man is cheated of, by his own Wife.

div.head: 36. Of Life, and Venus.
div.l: ALL actions labour, to atchieve their ends;
But Life, and Venus, are to it no friends.

div.head: 37. The Elyſian Fields.
div.l: GRand-ſire Aenaeas, (thank Poets) did come,
And view the levels of Elyſium:
But in thoſe times, he gave Eliſa due
Benevolence; the fiction proved true.

div.head: 38. The Cuckold, and Cuckold-maker. The Cuckold.
div.l: THis Wife I married; ſhe doth me forſake:
Not for your ſelves, O Bees! you hony make.

div.head: Cuckold-maker.
div.l: THeſe Boyes I got; another reaps the praiſe:
Not for your ſelves, O Birds! do you neſts raiſe.

div.head: 39. The new Rhetorick.
div.l: HEE that wants mony, labours but in vain,
In diſputations for to ſqueeze his brain:
Not he, who knows to ſpeak; but who, to give;
Under the roof of Rhetorick, ſhall live.

div.head: 40. Upon Cotta, lately turn'd a Monk.
div.l: COtta, vext with his treble-tongued Wife;
Betook himſelf to a Monaſtick life:
To ſee this hour, 'tis happy you were born;
If putting on a Hood, you put off Horn.

div.head: 41. The Arms of Geneva.
div.l: GEneva Bears the Eagle; and the key:
The firſt proclaims, Emperial Majeſty;
Unto the laſt, the Mitre, is right Heir,
Which is ſucceſſor to St. Peter's Chair.
Of pure Geneva's Arms, what will become,
If Caeſar takes the Eagle; the Key, Rome?

div.head: 42. Ʋpon the Poet Borbonius his toyes.
div.l: YOU call your verſes Trifles; be they ſo?
Ask your ſelf privately, and you'l hear, No.
I ſhall refrain my verdict; yet I may
Take leave to think, what you thought good to ſay.

div.head: 43. Faith.
div.l: FIdes, for Fiddle-ſtrings, is Plural; when
It Faith denotes, 'tis ſingular; ſay then,
Our Predeceſſors were Emphatical:
They held a ſingle Faith; that Faith was all.

div.head: 44. Upon Paulinus the Phyſician.
div.l: CALL you a ſick-man Patient, ſince hee
Is ſo impatient, of his Pains, and Thee?
With much adoe, you are endur'd: you may,
That he's your Patient, poſitively ſay:
His ſpirits by his ſickneſs, are much ſpent;
But 'tis the Doctor, which doth him torment.

div.head: 45. Upon Cottula.
div.l: IF Delphos did not flatter Socrates;
The attribute of Wiſe, claim when you pleaſe;
Proud Plato's Maſter may ſtand in your Row:
You know for certain, that you nothing know.

div.head: 46. Upon Fabiana.
div.l: LAnd bearing much, was fruitful call'd of yore;
Good Fabiana! Thou haſt born great ſtore.

div.head: 47. A Joque, upon the Covetous.
div.l: VVHat fooliſh humour, makes men ſo intent,
Natures contentedneſs to complement?
Whileſt on the other ſide, but few are nice,
To caſt ſtones at flint-hearted Avarice.
But little Nature craves; well, you'l grant us,
That nothing will ſuffice the Covetous.

div.head: 48. To a Lover of his Countrey.
div.l: 'TIs Honour to dye for my Countrey; fit:
Suppoſe Death may my Countrey benefit.
Yet to Live for my native Countrey, I
Humbly conceive more pleaſant, then to Dye.

div.head: 49. The World.
div.l: NO certainty; the world's turn'd upſide down:
What wonder then, that there no good is known?

div.head: 50. Ʋpon Aretine.
div.l: THings have their ſcantlings; but out trials find,
A meaſure hateful to fair Venus mind.
Luſt hath invented 1000 tricks; a part,
May Nature challenge; but the greater, Art.

div.head: 51. Ʋpon Silius.
div.l: PApiſts you might not be; nor could you love
The Proteſtants; thus Atheiſt did you prove.

div.head: 52. Upon Atheiſts.
div.l: NO houſe ſtands without owner; and will you,
Unto the worlds great Houſe, no Lord allow?

div.head: 53. The Phyſician.
div.l: SIr Mountebank will take gold, but none gives;
Phyſick will give, himſelf, without it lives.
The paunch Quack empties; his Pouch the diſeas'd;
One thing, to crave anothers help, is pleas'd.

div.head: 54. The Counſellor.
div.l: LAwyers by Law, are Juriſprudents named;
By their great wiſdom, Bumkin's title's lamed;
Let who will ſmart, they for themſelves provide;
No greater prudence, in the world beſide.

div.head: 55. The Courtier.
div.l: IF you be Good already, then in time,
You will be better; but ſcarce higher climbe:
If you be great already, in time you,
May become greater; but ſcarce better grow.

div.head: 56. Upon one-ey'd Marc.
div.l: ONe-eye wants honeſt Marc; one may ſuffice;
Diſcern more things, not better, can two eyes.
I have two ears; yet with thoſe never cou'd
Hear truth of things: two eyes; yet ſee no good.

div.head: 57. Upon Paul.
div.l: LEſt that your Name ſhould periſh, edifie
You will a tomb, fond man! that tomb, muſt die.

div.head: 58. A Receipt againſt Baldneſs. To Bithynicus.
div.l: NO fear in age you ſhould be Bald-pate cal'd;
Your youth (O happy Man) hath made you Bald.

div.head: 59. Upon Theodorus
div.l: THeodore marrying, was of the minde,
That now he heavens narrow way ſhould finde.
After experiment, the owl could ſay,
He found the road to Hell: the curſt, Broad-way.

div.head: 60. Apollo and the Muſes
div.l: FEmales are the Muſes; Apollo Male:
Nine Muſes can he ſingle, counter-vale.

div.head: 61. Upon Alanus now grown old.
div.l: ALanus wiſhing his cold limbs no harm,
Deſires his wife to turn; his place is warm.
Here's wit at will; Girls muſt not at Age ſpurn:
But laſt night Alan's wife had a good turn.

div.head: 62. New-years-Day.
div.l: TO the Rich, Olus ſends no New-years-Gifts;
Leſt they ſhould think he were put to his ſhifts.
Sending the poor 'tis Prudence to neglect;
From them, requital he can ſcarce expect.
Quintus to ſend, makes it his yearly task:
What he's aſham'd to beg, his Gifts ſhall ask.

div.head: 63. Upon Pontia.
div.l: HIs Wife told Pontius, there was a Law,
All Cuckolds ſhould be thrown, where Surges aw
The Mariner; Pontia in love to him,
Cry'd out, For God-ſake Husband! learn to ſwim.

div.head: 64. The Work of Darkneſs.
div.l: TO preſerve ſpecies from wing'd decay,
Then Individuums what's fitter pray?
Yet nothing more miſchievous is, then theſe
Soft Individuums, to Species.

div.head: 65. You Lie.
div.l: BEware to Souldiers, leſt you give the Lie;
There's no diſgrace like this indignity.
You Lie, it ſeems, is a deteſted phraſe:
To Lie, you love; that's little, no diſgrace.

div.head: 66. Upon an Hypocrite.
div.l: ALL Swearers, Superſtitious you'l controul;
Yet Lie all weathers; a religious Soul!

div.head: 67. Ʋpon an Hermaphrodite.
div.l: ANdrogynus may boaſt himſelf the Race
Of Mercury, and Venus, by his Face.
Not Male nor Female; (Bleſs me!) what's he then?
Ask Maids, a Man; a Woman, ask but Men.

div.head: 68. Venus.
div.l: LOve hath his Flux, and Reflux; Venus bred
Was in the ſoyl where Tethys layes her head.
No credit Venus merits; her deſcry
You may, 'twixt Sol, and ſeduc'd Mercury.
The Planets are her Croniſts: none ſo far
Can ſcout from ſenſe, to call her fixed ſtar.

div.head: 69. Ʋpon Rivals.
div.l: ALL Sutors, Phyllis would appropriate:
Call you it Love? 'tis Envy at this rate.

div.head: 70. A Woman.
div.l: IN that rich Language, which victorious Rome,
Bequeath'd to thoſe, Caeſars did overcome;
A Woman drew her name from Softneſs; 'cauſe
Mans brawny hardneſs they excell; by th' Lawes
Of benign Nature. Why ſo? 'tis well known,
Eve was not Adams Fleſh, but his hard Bone.

div.head: 71. The Relation betwixt Phyſicians and Lawers.
div.l: THE Lawyer, and Phyſician, for their pains;
Pick out of others Loſſes, legal Gains.
The Medic, heals the Body: Lawyers prate,
To cure the Falling-ſickneſs of Eſtate.
Both will aſſiſt each moment, whilſt you live;
If you ſubſiſt, each moment to Give, Give.

div.head: 72. To Philip concerning Pamphilus.
div.l: NAture defies a Vacuum: We ſee
How ſweetly She and Pamphilus agree.

div.head: 73. To Bald-pate.
div.l: TRees regain Hair; & Fields the verdant Graſs:
But when will your Head Leaf'd be, as it was?

div.head: 74. Nilus in my Eyes, Aetna in my Breſt.
div.l: A Briny Nilus overflowes my Eyes;
Whilſt with Aetnaean flames, my ſcorcht heart fryes.
Rivers of Tears, quench not my ardent Heat:
Nor my Loves Fire, dries up my Brains ſalt ſweat.
Water and Fire, in temper diſagree;
Yet will accord, ſo they may torture mee.

div.head: 75. If all things be alike. Ʋpon Camilla.
div.l: TWo Swaſhes did the fair Camilla court;
The one was handſome, but in ſtature ſhort;
The other Features could not boaſt at all;
But (like a May-pole) was exceeding tall.
Camilla being queſtion'd, which would do?
Exactly view'd them both, from top to toe.
Obſerving in the one, a Roman Noſe;
Long legs, long arms, ſhe prudently him choſe:
And modeſtly reply'd, None can miſlike
The proper man, if all things be alike.

div.head: 76. Of Gyants and Dwarfs.
div.l: TWo monſtrous creatures, land at Natures wharf;
The Gyant, is an Oxe; a Dolt, the Dwarf.

div.head: 77. Upon the ſpurious Off-ſpring of an Abbot.
div.l: VVHen you pray with the Covent; O how true
Is Abba Father, when pronounc'd by you!

div.head: 78. To Parſons.
div.l: A Prieſt, by marriage, did himſelf great wrong:
For wifes before did to his Tithes belong.

div.head: 79. A Participle.
div.l: A Verb is Eras; Mus, a Noun; pray paſs
Your Cenſure Reader, what Eraſmus was.

div.head: 80. A Cauſe for the Lawyers.
div.l: A Goatiſh man, led his own wife by chance,
(Suppoſing her his neighbours) Cupid's dance:
Admit a Childe the product of this Fate;
Is it a Baſtard, or Legitimate?

div.head: 81. The Morning.
div.l: IS it a wonder, light breaks forth before,
Phoebus begins, to blazon mountains Or?
Light as an elder Brother, did out-run,
By three daies journey, the life-giving Sun.

div.head: 82. Of Day.
div.l: LEt night with Argos have an hundred eyes:
Yet more with one, a duskiſh day deſcryes.

div.head: 83. Of Night.
div.l: HAth Night no other gown, but black aray?
Alas poor Widow! dead's her Husband-Day.
Were not Stars Lanthorns, to the mourning night;
We likewiſe might be vext, before Day-light.

div.head: 84. Ʋpon Marcus.
div.l: YOur Verſes praiſe me, Marc; I know theſe wayes;
You are ſo kind, that I, your verſe might praiſe.

div.head: 85. Death.
div.l: PEtty theeves may reſtore; nay high-way men:
Death never will; what a Jade is ſhe then!

div.head: 86. To his Friend.
div.l: HAlf you, your Miſtreſs claims; your ſelf I fear,
The other half; what part fals to my ſhare?
I reade you mine, in Complements thick ſown;
But are you Mine, when you are not your Own?

div.head: 87. A good Man.
div.l: IF ſcarcity will eſtimation bring;
Beleev't, a good Man is a precious thing.

div.head: 88. Ʋpon a certain old Man.
div.l: YOur beard, once black, cold age hath froſted gray;
Your mind, once white, is turn'd to black, they ſay.

div.head: 89. Upon Paulinus.
div.l: WHatever old acquaintance beg of you;
Yes, yes, to morrow; Paulin will it doe.
Muſt I be grateful, for the Gifts you ſend?
My thanks, until to morrow; I'le ſuſpend.

div.head: 90. Upon painted Dames.
div.l: YOU who delight to paint, need not forbear
To cry with Horace; Shadowes, duſt, we are.

div.head: 91. Ʋpon Cotta.
div.l: COtta his Wife is wholy; but not ſole:
Camilla ſoly his; I can't ſay, whole.

div.head: 92. The Politician.
div.l: DIſſemble what you know; let falſhood range▪
To finde the yeelding grain of every change.
Feel the pulſe of all times; that all may bee,
To thy deſires ſubſervient; good to thee.

div.head: 93. Upon Venus.
div.l: VEnus and Mars, play the unlawful game;
Becauſe in lawful ſporting, Vulcan's lame.

div.head: 94. Upon two Maſters.
div.l: NO man can ſerve two Maſters; I confeſs,
Marinus ſaith, I ſerve two Miſtreſſes.

div.head: 95. Ʋpon Marc.
div.l: YOur beard grows faſt, hairs fall off; thence is it,
Your beard becomes ſo long; ſo ſhort your wit.

div.head: 96. To Jo. Hoskins.
div.l: AT Wincheſter, a Boy; at Oxford, I
Being a youth; found your Fidelity.
In doubtful matters, you ſhew'd ſincere love:
And ſans deceit, to your truſt true did prove.
Of ſending this ſmall gift, Love was the ground;
To me, Love ty'd you; Me to you hath bound.

div.head: 97. Of Death: To Epicharmus.
div.l: EPicharm will not die; yet his own Breath
Wiſhes exhal'd; would die; but not by Death.
Sorrows bring death; Death ſorrows makes to fly:
Far worſe then death, is grating Miſery.

div.head: 98. Ʋpon Phyllis.
div.l: THe Parthians flying, backward caſt their darts:
By flying, Phyllis wounds her Lovers hearts.

div.head: 99. Ʋpon Hallus the Grammaticaſtre.
div.l: HAllus, whilſt hungry, cry'd, I'm hugely fam'd;
I'm hugely full; when his guts were reclaim'd.

div.head: 100. Of the Load-ſtone.
div.l: AS from all Iron, Load-ſtones do exact
Coition: ſo, Lords all the Gold, attract.
Courtiers I ask ye nothing: for ye are
Stingy in giving; what ye ask, ne'r care.
You give for your own ends; I cannot ſee
Gifts retrograde; I ſhall ſcarce ask of yee.

div.head: 101. Death.
div.l: ASk Me what Death is? pray ſtay till I die;
Come ask me then, your ſuit I ſha'nt denie.

div.head: 102. The Client.
div.l: CLients returning, before theefs may ſing:
For back from London they can't money bring.

div.head: 103. Ʋpon Zoilus.
div.l: I Blame bad manners; Zoilus you repine;
Perhaps miſdoubting, that, I aim'd at thine.
Then all the world, you are more fearful grown;
When I chide Vices, I may mean my own.

div.head: 104. Children and fools tell Truth.
div.l: THe Engliſh Proverb, cals ſuch Fools, as tell
The very Truth; a Liar bears the Bell.
Therefore if you ſpeak Truth, to Engliſh Men;
You may be for your labour, Fool cal'd, then.

div.head: 105. Ʋpon Bald-pate.
div.l: YOu had a thing, call'd forehead, when ſhook down,
The leaves were not, from your well-ſhaded crown.
But ſince the hair fel off; (with reverence,)
'Twixt head, and fore-head, there's no difference.
In jumbling head and face, age hath miſtook:
No credit can be given to your Look.

div.head: 106. To the ſame.
div.l: HOW many hairs I have, I can't divine:
Nor you, (for all are loſt) canſt number thine.

div.head: 107. An Apology for Fortune.
div.l: BAD Fortune is a fancy; ſhe is juſt:
Gives the poor, Hope; & ſends the rich, Diſtruſt.

div.head: 108. Ʋpon Cotta.
div.l: COtta went to a Bawd, to be befriended;
But did not return with his buſineſs ended.

div.head: 109. Ʋpon Procillus. A Noble.
div.l: IF you, Procillus! would no Liars hear:
That helliſh brood, your preſence would revere.

div.head: 110. To Paul, the Lawyer.
div.l: YOur practice eats the year; your worſhips ſalf,
If for your own, you Regiſter, one half
Your Wife will claim Vacations; by all Lawes,
You muſt be vacant, to attend her Cauſe.
The other part's ingroſt; when as a Quirk,
Non-ſuits your Wife; ſucceeds your Clients work.
The years moſt buſie months, are cal'd aright,
A term: They terminate your Wifes delight.

div.head: 111. To the ſame.
div.l: A Lawyer, Terms; Vacations, never ſees:
But alwaies findes the Leiſure to take Fees.

div.head: 112. To Marinus.
div.l: AS oft as your abuſed Wife, bewails
Your impotency; you ſhall feel her nails.
In vain you flatter; good words nothing can;
She muſt, and will have Satisfaction, Man!

div.head: 113. The Chirurgion.
div.l: MY Trade will flouriſh; Jove ſend peace, ſend war:
Venus, and Mars, both my kinde patrons are.

div.head: 114. The Venereal Diſeaſe.
div.l: BOrn an Italian; bred in France; quoth Fame,
Which Country ſtrives, to give the Pox a name?

div.head: 115. Calumniators. Flatterers.
div.l: OLD Anaxagoras, that ſnow was black,
Related; moſt like him, love truth to wrack.
Old Reynards ſuffrage, the Crow white decreed:
How many thouſand Foxes, Our age breed!

div.head: 116. Ʋpon Ponticus.
div.l: YOu have repented: I ſha'nt credit it;
None can repent, but they muſt have ſome wit.

div.head: 117. An Herculean labour.
div.l: IF ſtrong Alcides, his wifes tongue could tame;
A thirteenth labour, might augment his fame.

div.head: 118. War, Death.
div.l: WAr brings forth famin; famin is the cauſe,
That thruſts poor mortals, on the plagues ſharp jaws:
Then plague, or famine, two-edg'd war is worſe:
The humane glutton, ſupreme Jove's choice curſe.
War is the Alpha, of ſucceeding Wo;
Death the Omega of all trouble: ſo,
When Canons thunder, to fly Mars counts cheap,
From Alpha, to Omega, at one leap.

div.head: 119. Upon Cynthia.
div.l: THe gods conform your Nature, to your ſhape:
And to your Lilly-hand, be your minde, Ape.

div.head: 120. Ʋpon Gellia.
div.l: YOu ſin unſeen; that is a feign'd pretence:
You never ſin, but ſome give Evidence.

div.head: 121. Upon Albinus.
div.l: O Albin! Felix cry'd, your neighbor burn;
Home, home, with ſpeed; for next will be your turn.
Albin ſurpris'd his Horn-maker, at home;
And cry'd, Wiſe Felix! Faith my turn is come.

div.head: 122. Ʋpon Claudius, the raw Philoſopher.
div.l: GOod, hath three ſpecies; which are inclin'd,
To ſojourn in the body, eſtate, mind.
Sick, poor, and ſilly, Claudius we ſee;
He cannot challenge one, among theſe three.

div.head: 123. Ʋpon Bardella, the Mantuan Thief.
div.l: A Monk, Bardella, to be hang'd cheer'd up;
And ſaid, To night in heaven thou ſhalt ſup.
Bardel reply'd; This, I keep faſting-day,
If you pleaſe to accept my place, you may.

div.head: 124. Upon laſcivious Flora.
div.l: YOu tell of all your Bed-fellows; and ſo,
More hurt by prating, then by acting, do.

div.head: 125. Upon Quintil.
div.l: QUintil's friend can get nothing; Quintil's Laſs,
Hath got himſelf; and what e'r worth he was.

div.head: 126. To Aulus; concerning old Quintius.
div.l: CAn't Quintius marry, at decrepit years;
But Aulus, you muſt ſting him, with your jeers?
Why Epigrams? Epitaphs, beſt befit,
Old doting Lovers, that have loſt their wit.
An Elegie, (in all haſte) let him have;
For he hath dig'd already, his own grave.

div.head: 127. Upon Coſtus.
div.l: SCotfree he ſins; that's all Coſtus can plead:
But this fail'd, when, you know what loſt its head.

div.head: 128. An Anſwer to Cynthia's Letter.
div.l: YOu ſent white paper, but black was your Letter:
Your heart, and body; nothing expreſs better.

div.head: 129. To Sextilianus, A ſpurious Brat.
div.l: YOur Father, never purpos'd to create
You, Sextil! But himſelf, to recreate:
If we not Gifts, but Donors mindes, reſpect;
To Thank him for your Life, you may neglect.

div.head: 130. Upon Portia, an Hypocrite.
div.l: FIe! fie! your wit is bawdy: Good now grant
My Book that; which your Husband muſt not want.

div.head: 131. Saturn's three Sons.
div.l: THE corrupt Lawyer; dubious Divine;
Cheating Phyſician; the whole world enſhrine.

div.head: 132. Of ſingle-life, to a certain married Man.
div.l: THE wiſeſt King, ſaith, Wo to him alone:
Follow St. Paul, and Wives ye ſhall have none.
The wedded Man, cries, Wo to us; whilſt he,
Who ſtaies a Batchelor, cries, Wo to me:
Our wo is ſingle; but yours is not ſo:
You, and your Wife, muſt ſhare a double Wo.

div.head: 133. Ʋpon Corneus.
div.l: HEar, ſee, ſay nothing; obſerve for thy Life:
Since thou haſt got a wag-tail to thy wife.

div.head: 134. Upon Caius.
div.l: WHen lean Informers, Caius did eſpie,
To have two Wives; the Court they certifie.
Caius confeſt; and reſolute, them told,
What they condemn'd, he did moſt lawful hold:
One Wife, St. Paul, a Biſhop will allow;
I hope then, I, a Lay-man, may have two.

div.head: 135. Upon Pomponia.
div.l: POmponia ſets her ſelf to Farm; who's able
To praiſe her joyning Sweet, to Profitable?

div.head: 136. Upon Pinotus, ſick of the Cholick.
div.l: PInotus regain'd health; by loſing winde:
A Life, in that, which others kils; you finde.

div.head: 137. Upon Pomponia.
div.l: LOok how the Feather, daunces on her Hat;
'Twas Mars his badg; but Venus now gives that.
'Tis to grace Mars; Venus it deigns to wear:
This ſhews how friendly, Mars, and Venus are.
The Crow thinks her young ones fair.
Cicero Juſcul. Quaeſ. lib. 5.

div.head: 138. To H. L.
div.l: YOur neighbours wife, beſt contents you; and he,
Counts yours moſt fair; thus nobly ye agree.
Tully to prove his words, may now deſpair;
Some Birds (it ſeems) think their own chick's not fair.

div.head: 139. Venus.
div.l: YOu may hire Wenches, as well as buy Wines:
Why hath then Bacchus; and not Venus, ſigns?

div.head: 140. Things of worth, are hard to come by. To Marinus.
div.l: IF that fair Girls are nice, I'l chooſe the coy.
You may take leave, the coming to enjoy.

div.head: 141. Upon Theodorus.
div.l: TO marry, Goſpel will not you allow:
Not a pin-matter; the old Law will though.
But you have tranſgreſt Moſes Law, before:
Your laſt wife was a widow; firſt, a whore.

div.head: 141. New-years-Day, to Germanicus.
div.l: I Send you verſes, inſtead of a gift:
Return me gifts; verſes, you off may ſhift.

div.head: 143. Sara.
div.l: SHe that will let her Husband kiſſe her maid;
We ſhall ſcarce match, (good Sara) I'm afraid.

div.head: 144. To D. T.
div.l: YOu are your very Scholars ſervant; and
As your Lords School-maſter, you may command:
Whilſt thus you ſerve as Low; command as High;
Your Titles I both pity, and envy.

div.head: 145. Ʋpon Paula, the Atheiſt.
div.l: A Maid, two husbands, or a man two wifes,
Whether ſhould have; to ſolve it Paula ſtrives:
If you grant not a maid two Husbands; how,
Can in one fleſh conſiſt, the Plural two?

div.head: 146. Vertue conſiſts in a Mean.
div.l: A Superb woman, praunc'd betwixt two men;
Vertue her Medium had baniſht then.

div.head: 147. Ʋpon Acerra.
div.l: TO's Father Acer, ſingle did aver;
Happy is he, whom others horns deter.

div.head: 148. To Pinotus.
div.l: VVHat Laſs is for my Mony? ſuch an one,
As all would buy, but vendible to none.

div.head: 149. Ʋpon Quintus, and Quintina.
div.l: QUintus kneels to his wifes commands, as though
Commiſſion from the Gods, ſhe could avow.
Her words are Laws; poor Quintus trots about;
Thinks himſelf bleſt, his eyes are not ſcratcht out.
'Tis againſt nature, manners, vulgar ſpeeches;
Good Priſcian never give, women, the breeches.

div.head: 150. A Paradox. To his abſent Friend.
div.l: I Burn in Love; the more flames my deſire;
By how much further, I go from the Fire.

div.head: 151. Ʋpon Paulina.
div.l: PAulina her firſt husband, made a Stag;
Nor had the laſt, any great cauſe to brag.
She was as hard as horn, to firſt, and laſt;
But all the Interregnum, ſhe was chaſte:
Yet not for vertues Love, but her own ſake;
Knowing her Tinder, would but touch and take.
Although moſt urgent Gameſters, came apace;
In her Vacation, ſhe would give no Place.

div.head: 152. Upon Gellia.
div.l: IF to take Gifts for Benefices, be,
(Or ſuch like things) accounted Simonie;
Then you are guilty; who no fault at all,
Count to ſell Love: for love's ſpiritual.

div.head: 153. Ʋpon a certain Woman.
div.l: WIth wondrous ſpeed, in ſtature, large you grow:
Omicron the laſt year; Omega now.

div.head: 154. A Riddle.
div.l: TO finde this creature, whither ſhould I ſail,
Whoſe Father is a Woman; Mother, Male?

div.head: 155. To Ponticus.
div.l: IT Startled me, when your two eyes, I ſpy'd:
Since that your Father, Mother, were one-ey'd.

div.head: 156. Ʋpon Mr. Calf.
div.l: I Shall not ſay that horns ſprout on your skull;
But this I'le ſwear to; that you are a Bull:
What though a Bull? I ſhall not call you mad;
Although of late, your Cow, 3 Calves hath had.

div.head: 157. To a certain man, concerning a Dactyl.
div.l: WOuld'ſt Latin verſes to thy Mris. ſhow?
'Tis worth the while, what foot will pleaſe to know.
All women love, men ſhould in Dactyls court;
Which have one long ſyllable, and two ſhort.

div.head: 158. Love Deſcends.
div.l: LOve begins in the eye, by th' mouth deſcends;
Until at laſt, ſhe in her centre ends.

div.head: 159. Ʋpon a ſtammering Woman.
div.l: BAlba took leave, of Phi-phi-philip, thus;
Make quick return, and Cuc-cuc-comfort us.

div.head: 160. A problem for the Lawyers, concerning Theft.
div.l: TO take a thing without the Lords conſent,
Is Theft; what if the Lady be content?

div.head: 161. To Ponticus.
div.l: YOu promis'd fair, but nothing will give me:
Galen gives nothing; yet cries, Recipe.

div.head: 162. Upon Cerellia, married to Gallus, an Eunuch.
div.l: HAd not we (fools) the Spartan faſhion loath'd;
Then parties naked, ſhould have bin betroth'd.
Cerel in thought, had married a game-cock;
But Cock, prov'd Capon; craven'd by a Smock.

div.head: 163. Of Horns: A Problem.
div.l: A Wife is light, her husband wears the Horn;
Why ſo? He is her head; it muſt be born.

div.head: 164. On New-years-Day, to Germanicus.
div.l: YOur gifts, or elſe my Verſes, let me have:
Upon that ſame condition I them gave.

div.head: 165. Chriſt-Church Colledge in Oxford.
div.l: IMperfect you were left, in Wolſey's daies;
Yet you may claim, a Quadrangle of Praiſe.

div.head: 166. Ʋpon Phyllis.
div.l: PHyllis with pleaſure, doth my Rythms rehearſe;
But ſhe loves Venus, better then a Verſe.

div.head: 167. Of Himſelf.
div.l: I Spend the Time in trifling; and leſt thoſe
Years of my Life, ſhould periſh; I them loſe.

div.head: 168. To the Reader, concerning himſelf.
div.l: I Think this Brevity, my Fame can't hurt;
'Tis not a little Labour, to be curt.
The vulgar talk much, to ſmall purpoſe; I,
Perhaps talk Idle; yet uſe Brevity.

div.head: 169. Ʋpon Thraſo, the Braggadocio.
div.l: DOn't Thraſos gingling Heels, make a fierce ſhow?
Glory to all, is an huge Spur; you know.

div.head: 170. Of Himſelf.
div.l: JAmes the Apoſtle ſaith, Ask, and Receive:
O that K. James to me, would grant like leave.

div.head: 171. The Court-Muſick for two Voices.
div.l: 〈♫〉 One Courtier cry'd,
When others climbe, I ſhall my Self advance.
〈♫〉 T'other reply'd,
My Riſe muſt be, A Favourites miſchance.

div.head: 172. To the Reader.
div.l: LEt not my Book, Tobacco light; but rather,
Let it the Refuſe, of your Cloſe-ſtool, gather.

div.head: 173. To his Book.
div.l: MY Life perhaps, may my Books years, out-vie;
The Son, before the Father oft doth die.
But whether it dies firſt, or ſees Me Rot;
I underſtand, A Mortal, I begot.

div.head: 1. To the Reader.
div.l: LEt my Verſe not pleaſe Fools; the world is full;
I would not be the Darling, of a Gull.
Few Readers will ſuffice; grant me but one;
If no body me like, I'm pleas'd with None.

div.head: 2. To the Lady Mary Nevill.
div.l: OThers Renown, is but the Poets praiſe.
Your ſplendid glory, your own Merits raiſe.

div.head: 3. To the ſame.
div.l: IF you have Enemies, they need not fear;
To oblige friends, you make your chiefeſt Care:
This you obſerve; Friends, never to Forget:
Ne'r to Remember, with Foes, to cry Quit.

div.head: 4. To the ſame.
div.l: THat a fair Face, might beauty keep alive;
The curious Pencil, helps it to ſurvive.
I though a ſtranger, to the Limners Trade;
To keep your Fame alive, in Verſe eſſay'd:
Although Apelles Pencil, one Divine,
Should Draw: Apollo's Verſes her enſhrine.

div.head: 5. To Mr. J. H.
div.l: NO whit portentous, but a Poet I:
You are no Poet; but a Prodigie.

div.head: 6. What Newes?
div.l: ALL that know Me, my Patience thus abuſe;
Good Mr. Owen! hear you any News?
I Anſwer, I know None; and tell them True:
Of all I know, for I know nothing New.

div.head: 7. The Court.
div.l: HE, who to all Mens Humours, can't ſtoop down;
Hath got a fooliſh Humour; for his own.

div.head: 8. Ʋpon Aulus.
div.l: WHy were you made a Knight? becauſe that more,
Your wife might love you, then ſhe did before?
But you miſtook your ſelf; Sir Aulus, ſhe,
Will love her ſelf, the better; but not thee.
Former expence muſt double every yeer:
You ſhall have cauſe, to call your Lady, Deer.

div.head: 9. Upon the Chymiſt.
div.l: IT is the ſilly Chymiſts doting Fate,
To ſeek for Gold, and Loſe his whole Eſtate.
None muſt Elixar have, but He alone;
Till all away is ſquandred; Stick, and Stone.

div.head: 10. A Trojan.
div.l: AFter Troy's burning, the Trojans grew wiſe:
In this, True Trojan, who Himſelf denies?

div.head: 11. The Cure of Love.
div.l: BY frequent Faſtings, take wood from the Fire:
Let not a Ladies Glance kindle deſire.
If ſtill, your Fervour will not let you reſt;
A Wife will quench the Flame. Probatum eſt.

div.head: 12. Troynovant. To the Londoners.
div.l: NO Phoenix beautifies, the gilded Eaſt;
Before Sol lights her Mothers fragrant Neſt:
So decimated Troy, the Grecians burn:
Majeſtick London, ſprouts from Troy's pale Urn.

div.head: 13. The Lawyers God.
div.l: A Deity cal'd Term, Rome did adore:
But now at Weſtminſter He's Worſhipt more.

div.head: 14. The Earth.
div.l: TO charm our Tongues, the middle hath a Spell;
For there we think, the golden Mean doth dwel.
Therefore in play for Praiſe, earth throws an Ace,
Above the Heavens: here's the Middle place.

div.head: 15. To King James, De. of the Faith
div.l: YOu are Faiths chiefeſt Guardian; to intruſt,
Her, with your ſacred ſelf, Envy thinks Juſt.

div.head: 16. To the Lord Treaſurer.
div.l: A Treaſurer, whom Vertue makes to hold,
Vulturian Talons, from the Regal Gold:
Is Himſelf greater Treaſure, then can ſhine,
In the Rich womb of an Exchequers Mine.

div.head: 17. To the Kings chief Secretary.
div.l: THe Secrets of three Florid Nations lie,
Committed to your Teſted Secrecie.
The Kings thoughts are not ſafe, till in the Cheſt,
They be lockt up; of your moſt Tacid Breaſt.

div.head: 18. To the Venetians.
div.l: A Fair laid your Foundations, at the firſt.
Neptune, turn'd Foſter-father; and them nurſt.
Nor ſhall mute Fiſh, the Sea Monopolize;
Your Palaces, make proud waves pay excize.
The Sea now fetter'd, gives a City Birth;
Art baffling Nature, water turn'd to Earth.
Your Empire ſurvives time; waves ebb, and flow:
Yet never dare unconſtant prove, to you.
It is not ſtrange, Venice her ſelf, loves Lawes;
Since ſhe, the out-law'd Ocean, over-awes.

div.head: 19. To the Lord Chancellor.
div.l: LEſt that the Quirks, or Rigour of the Laws,
Should accidentally, Injuſtice cauſe;
Deſervedly it in your power doth lie,
To bridle Common-Law, with Equitie.

div.head: 20. To the Lord Richard Sacvil, Earl of Dorcheſter.
div.l: YOur Anceſtors were Noble; you, we ſee,
The glory of renew'd Nobilitie.
For you, (which was a Wonder in old time,
Seems now Prodigious, to our vicious Clime)
Rewards attending Merits, diſreſpect;
Love prudent Lawes; devaſting Arms neglect.
To prefer Vertue, before Power, think good;
And Learning's Jewel, before Noble Bloud.

div.head: 21. Cecil Lord Treaſurer. 1597.
div.l: ARms abroad are invalid; unleſs that
Prudence at Home, and Cecil, ſteer the State.
Cecil, is Atlas Brother; born Above:
Cecil, Props up Eliſa; Atlas, Jove.

div.head: 22. Ʋpon the Lord William Cecil's Motto.
div.l: Virtute Duce, Comite Fortuna:
Vertue my Leader, Fortune my Companion.
DIvine Elizabeth, Fortune did grace,
(Your wiſht Companion) with an Earls high place:
Since there was None, her Pleaſure durſt Rebuke;
Why made She not, Vertue your Leader, Duke?

div.head: 23. To Richard Vaughan, Biſhop of London.
div.l: YOu Britiſh Honour! are the firſt from Wales,
Arriv'd at Londons Sea; through happy Gales.

div.head: 24. To the ſame.
div.l: THoſe Doctors alwaies pleas'd me, who account,
Their good Lives, their good Sermons to ſurmount.
Moſt learned Biſhop! you, not only teach,
Others their duty, but by Life do Preach.

div.head: 25. To Tho. Bilſon, Biſhop of Wincheſter.
div.l: YOu were my School-maſter; let who will, know;
All theſe I write, I to your Precepts owe.

div.head: 26. The Life of William of Wicham, formerly Biſhop of Wincheſter; publiſht in Latine, by Tho. Martin, Doctor of the Civil Law.
div.l: THat a dead Man, a Perſon ſhould have freed,
From deaths black Dungeon; few wil make their creed.
Had you not don this work, in Lethe's Brook
You had bin drown'd; now both, live by this Book.

div.head: 27. Wincheſter Colledge.
div.l: EUrope's chief School, our Wincheſter appears;
Where I was honour'd to ſpend younger years▪
To give her the firſt place, Zoilus is bound;
Suppoſe he knows, great Wicham, did her Found.

div.head: 28. Sir Philip Sidney.
div.l: BEcauſe old Homer did his Praiſes ſing,
Achilles was thought happy, by the King,
Of large Aemathia, Poor wretch am I,
Whoſe Muſe can't divine Philip, Deifie.

div.head: 29. To the ſame.
div.l: VVHo acts things, worthy to be writ, or writes,
Things worth the Reading; on no ſmall bliſs lights.
No Plummet ſounds your Repute; who alone,
By a rare Genius make theſe Two, but One.
Readers your Writings covet; ev'ry Act,
Might all Hiſtorians Table-books, exact.
Your writings prove you Learned; Deeds atteſt,
That Proweſs Anchors, in your noble Breſt.
FOr Nature, Wiſdom, Beauty, Age, Eſtates,
Nobility, ye are moſt equal Mates:
Yet Sir, I this confeſs; you have not wed
So Nobly, as deſerv'd, your Bridal-bed.
And I acknowledge Madam; that you are,
Worthy a Husband, yours, excelling far.

div.head: 31. To Elizabet, Counteſs of Rutland, Daughter to Sir Philip Sidney.
div.l: RAre Philip's Praiſe, did not on Error trip;
Since he was Father, to your Ladiſhip.
That was his Honour: Yours is for to be
Daughter, to ſuch Heroick Chivalrie.

div.head: 32. To Lucia Counteſs of Bedford.
div.l: LIght gave (as God-mother) your honour Name;
That through the world might ſhine, your Lucid Fame,
You for your Birth, to noble Parents owe;
But wit, and Vertue, you the Light, did ſhow.

div.head: 33. The Knights Ring. To Sir Henry Goodyear.
div.l: LEt Honour be the Gold, Vertue the Stone;
Until that Ring, your Finger leaves alone.

div.head: 34. To Mr. J. H.
div.l: YOur Verſes deſerve well, yet want Applauſe:
Some Writers are much prais'd, for little cauſe.

div.head: 35. To D. B.
div.l: IF he who keeps things cloſe lives well, then you:
You hide your Faculties, they greater ſhow.

div.head: 36. To Th. M. the Princes Tutor.
div.l: TO a Decorum, you the Prince do bring,
Will make him of himſelf; as Britains King,
Rule of himſelf, all other will out-vie;
This one, excels the Four-fold Soveraigntie.
This one laid in the Balance, will weigh down
Babylon, Perſia, Grecia, Romes proud Crown.

div.head: 37. To the ſame.
div.l: NOw Age makes our Prince docil, his green youth
Imbibes grave Precepts from your learned mouth:
O Teach him ſo! that future times may ſay,
Our King is great, good, learned; which bears ſway?

div.head: 38. To Mr. Walter Gwyn.
div.l: YOu make the Princes happineſs compleat,
By PropheſiesIn an Anagram, that Mr. Gwyn made in Scotland, before the Union of it, with England. , flouriſh in Arthur's Seat.
Nature hath given Parts; let Fortune be
As much profuſe, in her Indulgencie.
And as the Prince grows bigger, I wiſh you,
May ſwell in Honour, and ſtill greater grow.

div.head: 39. Francis Drake. 1581.
div.l: DRake hath embrac'd the Word; and did eſpy,
Both Polar Tenter-hooks, which hold the sky.
If men be ſilent, Stars will blaze thy Fame:

And So •
will Trumpet, his Dear Comrades Name.
Drake did but bait at Calpe; and may cry,
Great was Alcides; true, but Greater I.

div.head: 40. Britains Strength. To the Prince.
div.l: HAvens, are England's Gates; the Navy, Wals;
Sea, Tents; works, Bodies; and Hearts, Admirals.

div.head: 41. The Terreſtrial Globe.
div.l: WAter, & Earth, make but one Globe; 'tis ſtrange;
For Earth moves not; the waters, always range.

div.head: 42. The mad way to Health.
div.l: THe more Healths in your Belly ſwim; the leſs
Shall your drown'd Body, dwell with healthfulneſs:
I envy not your thouſand Healths; to me,
A ſingle Health, is a ſufficiency.
It is the only Health, no Healths to drink:
In drinking Healths, there is no Health; I think.

div.head: 43. The Divine.
div.l: YOur knowledge, is a Cypher, without you,
To light your Brothers Candle, it allow.

div.head: The Politician.
div.l: MY Brother ſhall be hang'd firſt, before I,
Reveal one tittle, of my Myſtery.

div.head: 44. All things deſire that which ſeems Good.
div.l: DOth Optimus from Opto ſteal its Name?
The Beſt, to Wiſh; in Latin ne'r the ſame.
Why may not this be ſo, ſince none can reſt
From Wiſhing; (except Fools) what they think Beſt?

div.head: 45. A Black Swan.
div.l: A Maid of Burgundie, lean as a Rake
Made by Green-ſickneſs; was advis'd to take
Sedum minus 2 M. which ſome vow,
As rare an Herb, as can in Gardens grow.
The Pious Maid, her Doctor did deny:
Choſe before ſin, Sins wages; and would Die.

div.head: 46. Democritus, and Heraclitus.
div.l: DEmocritus, laught at what e'r befell:
Plague, Famine, Murders; ſtil the World went well.
At Feaſts, at Weddings, brewing briniſh Tears;
Sad Heraclitus, with ſore eyes appears.
Shall we weep for Heraclitus? or thus,
Shall we laugh at merry Democritus?

div.head: 47. Ʋpon Langa.
div.l: LAnga a Papiſt, wedded to a Man,
That did Profeſs himſelf a Lutheran.
To prevent Future ſtrife, Husband! ſaid ſhee,
I'l make (for once) this fair offer, to Thee:
Grant me but Free Will; and then there's an end:
About the other Points, I ſha'nt contend.

div.head: 48. King Arthurs Round Table.
div.l: VVHy did Heroick Arthur, ſo much care
For a Round Table; and rejected ſquare?
Not without Reaſon; for Gods work is Round:
But humane heads, the Quadrature have found.

div.head: 49. To Theophila. B. C.
div.l: HE muſt be zealous; in Brains no whit dull;
Who can ye Love; or praiſe unto the full.

div.head: 50. Ʋpon Hernicus.
div.l: HIs Soul to Heaven, Body, to the Grave,
Commended Hernicus; about to leave
This ſinful world: but hearing that his Wife,
Would quickly period her Widows Life;
In very anger, he recal'd his Breath:
But before that, he was reſolv'd for Death.

div.head: 51. Of Love, and Faith.
div.l: LOve, and Faith, are divorc'd; we know it thus;
Faith is ſuſpected; Love, ſuſpicious.

div.head: 52. The Lover.
div.l: UNcertain Hope, ſhort Pleaſures, conſtant Fears,
Joy-grief, ſweet Pains, fall to poor Lovers ſhares.

div.head: 53. The Golden Age.
div.l: WHen to fill Bags with Gold, men did not rage;
Why did they call ſuch Times, the Golden Age?

div.head: 54. Ʋpon Alana.
div.l: NAture ordain'd you, to Lie under; yet,
At Table uppermoſt, be ſure, you'l ſit.
Thus Man, and Wife, finde out Pacifique waies;
He rules the Roſt, by Night; She rules the Daies.

div.head: 55. The German Death. To Polynicus.
div.l: NOt to be, Death; grave Seneca did think:
But Germany ſuppoſeth, Not to drink.

div.head: 56. Ʋpon Philodemus.
div.l: OF ſcarce Commodities you hate the Price;
But to take common (if cheap) are not Nice.
I'le tell you what, (becauſe a friend of Mine)
A cheap coſts more, then a dear Concubine.

div.head: 57. Ʋpon Long-tongue.
div.l: BAttus talks like a fool; and then of courſe
Comes out; Pray pardon Sir, my long Diſcourſe.
No want of Pardon, ſhould to you belong;
If you could learn the Art to hold your Tongue.

div.head: 58. The Gordian Knot.
div.l: WAS the ſtrain'd Gordian Knot, rather unty'd
By the Kings Wit; or did his Sword divide?
Without wit you may untye this Knot: but,
Were Alexander here; He could not Cut.

div.head: 59. Love.
div.l: WAr, Peace; Peace, War; ſuch faults are found in Love:
For Love, from ſtrife; doth ſeldom far remove.

div.head: 60. The Laws. The loſs of Quiet. To the Lawyers.
div.l: STrife, breeds Laws; Laws, Strife; without ſtrife, no Man
Uſeth to live; without the Laws none can.

div.head: 61. The Covetous, and the Prodigal.
div.l: THe Prodigal affects high, poliſht ſtrains;
Nothing but Rhetorick, coms neer his Brains.
The Covetous, in Logick, takes delight:
And ſcrapes up Syllogiſms, day, and night.
For Avarice, Logicks cloſe fiſt, we call
Suadas broad Palm, denotes the Prodigal.

div.head: 62. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Labour, or Trouble.
div.l: PAin, was ſcarce Labour; to moſt Active Rome:
To Idle Greece, Labour was Troubleſome.

div.head: 63. A Good man, Valiant, Wiſe.
div.l: GOod men, have ſeldom wealth; or ſtout men, wit:
And to Beleeve a Wiſe Man, few think fit.

div.head: 64. The Order, of the Golden-Fleece.
div.l: FRom Philip Duke of Burgundie, ſaith Fame;
The Order of the Golden-Fleece, firſt came:
His Heir, now wears, Rich Peru's Regencie:
This was no Order, but a Propheſie.

div.head: 65. Tho. Earl of Dorcheſter's Motto.
div.l: Nec Temere, nec Timide.
Not Raſhly, not Cowardly.
WIſely Deſpair of all things; Boldly Hope:
Beware of all things; yet ſcorn fear to cope.

div.head: 66. Sir Tho. Nevil's Motto.
div.l: Ne vile velis.
Scorn Baſeneſs.
LEt not vain, or Vile things thy Honour ſtain:
Vile things are worth but little; Nothing vain.

div.head: 67. To Sir Phil. Sidney, concerning his Arcadia.
div.l: YOu did at Death, (witneſs your wife) command,
That your Arcadia, through ſome bloudy hand,
Should give a Treat, to the Impartial flame:
And like a Phoenix Neſt, perfume thy Name.
But if the Crime be fatal, that hot Fires,
Were by it kindled, in Lovers deſires;
Thoſe queint Lines, by more Juſtice had been ſent
A preſent, to the watry Element.
But let your Book be ſentenc'd; ev'ry vote,
Proclaims your wit, ſhall reach times higheſt Note.

div.head: 68. To the moſt learned Gentlewoman, Mris. Jane Owen.
div.l: I Never heard of, nor did ever ſee,
Thoſe Siſters, a Fifth Father, gave to Thee.
Therefore how many, and how Qualifi'd;
By unacquaintance, could not be deſcry'd.
Yet what they are, (Dear Jane!) I full well know;
If't be their happineſs, to be like you.

div.head: 69. To his Friend.
div.l: THough I hate none, I'll not be twice a Friend:
My Friendſhip once begun, ſhal ne'r have End.

div.head: 70. The Ʋſurers Grammar.
div.l: TAke Bird, Beaſt, Fiſh, or any creeping thing;
This, that, all theſe, acknowledge Love their King.
Yet Mr. Gold, Dame Plate, a thing call'd Caſh;
Compar'd with Love; proves that proud Victor, Traſh.

div.head: 71. To one, like neither of his Parents.
div.l: WHy do you neither Parent repreſent;
Since Both at your conception, gave conſent?
Not Fathers, Mothers Features, can you ſhow:
For Both, ſtrove joyntly, when they begot you.

div.head: 72. To two concealing their Names, at their Return from Venice.
div.l: YOu went to Venice, to ſeek four-fold Gains,
To fill your purſes; and reward your pains.
Since ye got good; your friends were wel content,
That ye return'd; though to their detriment.

div.head: 73. Adultery, and Fornication.
div.l: THe idle Fornicator, Pray, how far,
Differs he from the looſe Adulterer?
I ſhall reſolve this Queſtion, if I can:
As much as Comick, and Tragoedian.

div.head: 74. Concerning Hercules. To C. D.
div.l: NO Monſter could Alcides hurt; yet Love,
Trampled upon him; and ſate Queen above.
A Lion could not; a Laſs made him yeeld:
Not Beaſts with Four, but Two Legs, won the field.

div.head: 75. A friendly Salute.
div.l: I Deſire Phyllis, three kiſſes to have;
At leaſt as many as your Lips, I crave.
She lends Me one; is paid; yet denies Two:
Take thine, or give me mine; why this adoe?

div.head: 76. A Problem to the Naturaliſt concerning a Kiſs.
div.l: EIther a Kiſs, to taſte, belonging is;
Or why moſt proper, by the Mouth, to Kiſs?

div.head: 77. To Labiemus.
div.l: THis is Promotion; Heaven, waites on Me;
Quoth Labiemus, at the Gallow-Tree.

div.head: 78. Ʋpon Alexander.
div.l: TO Philip's Son, a world, gave not content:
Though he Rul'd North, South, Weſt, the Orient.
Though we the world, vaſtly dilated finde;
It was too narrow, to contain his Minde.
To Philip's Son, the world prov'd much too vaſt;
For his long Arms to claſp it in the waſt.
Though he was Great, by Actions; Great, by Birth:
Yet this Great Man, was Leſſer then the Earth.

div.head: 79. To Firmicus, againſt Aulus.
div.l: YOu Beleeve none; yet Firmicus, I ſee
No Man ſuch Sceptic, but will Beleeve, thee.
What others tell, you Aulus, ſuck all in:
But for your News, no Man would give a Pin.

div.head: 80. Ʋpon a certain Verſifier.
div.l: YOu drink, as if, none could a Poet be;
Without from Ale, they learn the Myſterie.
You ſwill, as if, the Muſes lend an Hand
To none; but thoſe, whom Beer forbids, to ſtand.
When drunk, you Rhythm, without all wit, or Fear:
You may love drink; your ſelf, an Hogs-head are.

div.head: 81. Upon certain Lying Letters.
div.l: I Frequenly receive Lines you endite:
But ſeldom, never, do you Goſpel write.

div.head: 82. Phyſician, heal your ſelf. To Gilbert.
div.l: I Bid you, minde your ſelf; yet might Neglect:
You for your ſelf, have ſingular Reſpect.

div.head: 83. Ʋpon a certain Ʋſurer.
div.l: IN a good Mood, you lent an Hundred Pound,
To Flava; now ask Uſe; but on what Ground?
If you get Principal, 'tis an Abuſe,
To require more; her Body, paid you Uſe.
Quod non habet in Aere, luat in Corpore.

div.head: 84. Upon an Hypocrite.
div.l: QUite through your life, you diſſemble; or feign:
Though Fiction is a Labour; th'other, Pain.

div.head: 85. Eraſmus his Encomium Moriae.
div.l: ERaſmus was the Firſt, writ Folly's Praiſe:
Folly requited, and his Fame did raiſe.

div.head: 86. The Anagrammatiſt.
div.l: WHat a ſtir here's with Vowels? here, and there,
The Letters fly; to light, I know not where.
So by Auguſtus Favour; to their Coats,
Thyrſis drove Sheep; and Corydon, the Goats.

div.head: 87. To a certain ſilly Doctor.
div.l: BEardleſs of late, and very weak, in Parts;
You ſeem'd a Maſter, of the Seven Arts.
But now you are a Doctor; no Beard want:
But yet hang Him, that is more Ignorant.

div.head: 88. Love is Naked.
div.l: NAture cloathes Fields, with Graſs; and Beaſts, with Hair:
Birds have their Plumes; Sheep, warm in Fleeces are.
What ever Animal, is Born; or Bred;
By Nature; or by Art, is covered:
But why ſhould Love, to Nakedneſs, be ſold
Alone? becauſe it Naked, feels leaſt cold.

div.head: 89. Concerning the Exchequer. To Sir Will. Pits.
div.l: MOney collected, runs into the chinks,
Of the Exchequer; ſo Sea, Rivers drinks.
Money diſperſt, flies from't as faſt; as though,
A thouſand Rivers, from the Sea ſhould flow.
And yet the Sea, is not full ſatisfy'd:
Nor laviſh ſtreams of Cryſtall Rivers dry'd.

div.head: 90. Upon one Perfidious.
div.l: I Was too creculous; that made me Heir,
To Unbelief: Falſe Hopes, taught me Deſpair.

div.head: 91. The ſin of the Silver Age.
div.l: ALL Saturn's gilded Reign, Whores did defie:
Till Jove was King; the world, woo'd Purity.

div.head: 92. A Baud.
div.l: YOur Body is all ſold; and you much ſcoul,
Becauſe you want a Chapman, for your Soul.
Who buys a Soul! but none is ſo unwiſe,
(Except Don Beelzebub) to give your Price.

div.head: 93. Ʋpon Self-Love.
div.l: HE's the third Perſon; Second, Thou; firſt, I:
No Third, but loves the Firſt's, Supremacy.

div.head: 94. Wiſdome.
div.l: WHo's Rich? a Wiſe Man; who is Poor? Unwiſe:
Therefore if I have wit; my Bags will riſe.
Who's Wiſe? a Rich man; who's a Fool? one Poor:
Either I muſt be Rich, or Fool, therefore.

div.head: 95. The Etymologie of Venus.
div.l: VEnus, A Veniendo,De Nat. Deorum. Lib. 2. Tully ſayes;
Becauſe to all ſhe comes, without delayes.
But in another ſenſe, her Name I hold;
'Cauſe ſhe comes oft to Markets; to be ſold.

div.head: 96. To a certain Pox-catcher.
div.l: IF Gold were as much Drunk, as Coveted;
Thy Guts would make a Royal Mine; indeed!

div.head: 97. To Polla.
div.l: YOu deny Kiſſes unto None; none Kiſs:
But to their Mouths, your Cheek, reverted is.
The Name of New, and Old, is not the ſame:
Your new-found Kiſſing, ſhould have a new Name.

div.head: 98. A Friend. A Wife.
div.l: SOuls are moſt Dear; hence Friends, love not to part:
But how comes thy Wife, ſo? ſhe's thy deer Heart.

div.head: 99. Anger.
div.l: BEcauſe it Vertue ſpurns, I conjecture;
The Stagyrite miſcall'd it, Vertues Spur.

div.head: 100. The Roman Flora.
div.l: TAxes on the whole World, were by Rome laid;
Yet this Great City to the Tribute paid.
For what, for Hackney-hire, was given you;
Was but as Tribute, to your Beauty due.

div.head: 101. The Etymologie of Anger.
div.l: ONe Angry, is perplext; ſo ſaith the Name:
Anger, and An-gor, are almoſt the ſame.

div.head: 102. Of Himſelf.
div.l: VVHilſt light things, I touch ſoberly; I may
Be rightly ſaid; to ſtudy; as I Play:
Whileſt I write ſober things, with a Light Pen;
My Play, may be to Study compar'd, then.

div.head: 103. Womens Titles of Honour.
div.l: LEt an Earl take to wife, a Countrey Girl;
She is a Counteſs; becauſe He, an Earl.
But let a Counteſs marry meanly; She,
Adds not one Atom, of Gentilitie.
So Phoebus gilds, the Lady of the night;
But ſcorns to vapour, in a Borrow'd Light.

div.head: 104. Upon Zoilus.
div.l: HE that will others praiſe, and bears an heart,
Brim-full with Love; ſhall himſelf, help to part
The Stakes, with Men belov'd; & prais'd: commend;
Thou canſt not want Requital; in the end.

div.head: 105. The middle Age is unknown.
div.l: BEfore the laſt Line of our Life ſhall trace
The Grave; no Line, deſigns the Middle ſpace,
What to be cal'd the Middle Age, is grown,
Through Cuſtom; before Death, cannot be known.

div.head: 106. To a Dyer waxing Gray.
div.l: YOur Beard was Black; but now 'tis turn'd to Gray:
Not Art, but Nature, found out this fine way.

div.head: 107. To the Courtier.
div.l: PRoud Rome, Superbus, to diſgrace did bring;
What wonder? Pride, did never love a King.
Kings have not many friends; a Reaſon why?
Becauſe the Scepter, deteſts Parity.

div.head: 108. Bed.
div.l: WHat Engliſh call a Bed, the Welch call Grave:
A Bed, and Tomb, Death, Sleep; Reſemblance have.

div.head: 109. Rider's Bibliotheca.
div.l: COnceited Rider, merited great Blame;
When he his Book, a Library did Name.
One Book, can't make a Library; Grave on
His heap of words, the Title, Lexicon.

div.head: 110. Money.
div.l: To derive Nummus, and Numiſma, ſeek?
Nummus denotes Money told out; Upon
This Fancy, Number, will give Etymon.
But I can derive't better; Money is,
In all Mens Thoughts; the chief of Goddeſſes:
This once premis'd, it fals into our Road;
Nummus à Numine; As Gold, from God.

div.head: 111. Upon Covetous I. S.
div.l: YOur Gates are Iron; you in Iron, hoard
Your Gold; your Houſe is Iron; Iron, its Lord.

div.head: 112. Of Roman Flora. To the Grammarians.
div.l: TO Flora, Rome, did Flowers ſacrifice;
And her the goddeſs of Flowers, deviſe.
But ſhe, of a good Name, was Prodigal;
And therefore never brought forth fruit, at all:
But being wanton, in her youthful Flower;
Flower, and Fruit, that Canker did devour.

div.head: 113. Upon John Protus.
div.l: AS tepid Autumn, by ſeverer Blaſts;
Trees verdent Beauty, on the low ground, caſts:
So Calvus had a trick, to ſhake his Crown;
Till he ſhak'd fair; for ev'ry hair, fell down.

div.head: 114. Ʋpon Theodorus.
div.l: WHen as King David was, Threeſcore, & Ten;
A florid Virgin warm'd his cold ſides, then.
You to do like him, who a Prophet was;
Have clapt at your old back, a plump young Laſs.

div.head: 115. To a certain Gentlewoman.
div.l: WEre Fortune to you ſo Propitious, as
Nature Profuſe, in your endowments was:
Had your Commands, Troy faſtned to the Stake;
It would have kiſs'd the flames; 'cauſe for your ſake.

div.head: 116. The great Peſtilence. 1603.
div.l: SO many Souls, this Sickneſs, ſent to Styx;
There is ſcarce room, for a new plague to fix.

div.head: 117. Ʋpon a perjured perſon, convicted, by his own Hand-writing.
div.l: IN vain by Oath, did you confirm a Lie;
Since your Hand detects, which you can't denie,
That Deeds, might exceed Words; God only gave
Your Bodies Form, to challenge one mouth leave.
Since God gave but one Tongue; and yet, Hands Two:
What makes Hand, ſingle; your Tongue double ſo?

div.head: 118. Upon Cottula, the Grammaticaſtre.
div.l: THe Greek word Labyrinth, you well expound;
By telling us, Labour-in-it is found.

div.head: 119. The Anagram of Roma. To the Carthaginians.
div.l: HAnnibal took not Luck, when 'twas his courſe:
Not well conſidering, the Roman Force.
The way to Conquer, was known to this Man;
But (though he were a ſubtle African)
He was found Ignorant, to uſe his Lot.
So, many ſtrike not whilſt the Iron's hot.
Roma, by Mora; Little Delay, More
Then fit; made Rome as Great, as once before.

div.head: 120. To a certain Great Clerk.
div.l: VVHere is Concoction, in a ſick mans Feaſt?
You know much, I confeſs; Nothing, digeſt.

div.head: 121. Ʋpon one Davis.
div.l: TO boaſt your ſelf of Cockney, you think good;
Leſt ſom ſhould ſay, you were of Britiſh Bloud.
You refuſe that, (which would a Wiſe Man grace)
To procure deſcent, from an obſcure Race.
You, and your Countrey, Ill; yet well, Agree:
You are aſham'd of that; and that, of Thee.

div.head: 122. Upon Aulus.
div.l: FOols, count thee wiſe; Wiſe Men, A Fool i'th' Height:
What art I prethee, in thine own Conceit?

div.head: 123. Upon Doctor Linus.
div.l: YOu wholly Act Formalities; but why,
Do you ſlight Learning? Form gives Entity.
If any dare, this Axiom's Truth invade;
I prove it thus; Form, Linus, Doctor made.

div.head: 124. Upon Thais.
div.l: VVOuld Handſomeneſs were leſs; or Goodneſs more:
Nothing is worſer, then a Beauteous Whore.

div.head: 125. Upon a great Scribler, aſhamed to affix his Name.
div.l: WHen cruel Hunger, did gag up thy Jawes;
And untam'd thirſt, to cry Fire, gave the cauſe;
You like a Mad man, Idle Pamphlets made:
What's your excuſe? Ah! Hunger, did perſwade.
Curſt Poverty, makes you like Tereus Sup;
You beget Children; and then, eat them up.

div.head: 126. Ʋpon Mr. No-Hair.
div.l: ON this ſide, that ſide, before, and behinde;
I ſearch your Head: yet not one Hair can finde.
Since Ev'ry Hair, hath its Plantation fled;
What can you next loſe Calvus? what? My Head.

div.head: 127. To Claudius, and Linus.
div.l: NOthing wants to make Claudius good; but Wil:
Nothing but Power; to make Linus, Ill.

div.head: 128. To George.
div.l: IF you will be in my Book, which you ſee,
Guilty enough of lazy Poetrie; case Nom.
If the Praiſe of your Family, I take case Gen.
For Theme; of you I'll ſeldom mention make:
Or if to give ye thanks, my verſe ſhould ſtrive;
To you (as you deſerve) I cannot Give.
My Love, and liking do to you belong; case Dat.
'Cauſe you are not accus'd in any Song. case Accu.
Or noble George! ſhall I upon you call? case Voc.
Then you muſt ſit, inferiour to all.
And to ſpin out longer Diſcourſe, with you; case Abl.
My Muſe is willing: but ſhe knows not how.

div.head: 129. Every Lover, is a Souldier.
div.l: VVEnches to Souldiers, Aulus did compare:
Men pleaſe Mars arm'd; Venus, when naked are.

div.head: 130. The Military Oath.
div.l: THe Latines call that Oath, a Sacrament;
Which to New Leaders, Times of war preſent.
If that a Sacrament, be but juſt ſo;
The Pope is right: for there are more then Two.

div.head: 131. Upon Covetous and Cripled Alanus.
div.l: ARe Gifts to maim'd Alanus, gratis ſent?
He then, Briareus can repreſent.
But if you think, a Recompence to ſee;
His hundred Hands, prove Lame; immediately.

div.head: 132. The Condition of Kings.
div.l: ONe loves not to tell Truth; Another fears:
This greateſt Miſery, fals to Kings ſhares.

div.head: 133. Vis. Jus. The Anagram of Jus, the Law, is Vis, Force.
div.l: THe Law diſguſteth Force; Force, Law; both bee
In Name, good Friends; but Natures diſagree.

div.head: 134. Ʋpon Marcus.
div.l: VVIth Wifes, with Widows, Chamber-maids, your Life
Is lewdly ſpent; but a Fig for your Wife.
Let who will Ask, your Back, ſcorns to ſay no:
Any thing, but what's Lawful; you will do.

div.head: 135. Deſperate Debt.
div.l: MEn are bound to their wifes; but who dares ſay,
He hath enough, the Total ſum to pay?
For though ſome to have paid, may make pretence;
Yet they ſtill owe, a due Benevolence.

div.head: 136. Ʋpon Culianus.
div.l: A Wiſe Man is aCicero de Diu. lib. 2. Miracle; but now,
They are all ceas'd; our Times no wiſe Man know.
But Culian you have wit; I can't deviſe,
If Miracles be ceas'd; you ſhould be Wiſe.

div.head: 137. Upon Beautiful Marc.
div.l: VEnus did Fire, your Tenement of Luſt:
In all Spectators eyes, you are Venuſt,

div.head: 138. Upon Adrian the Fifth.
div.l: YOur ſilly Epigrams; your dull Verſe, fears
It ſhould endure the ſting, of acute Jeers.
Though they are not Facetious; Readers ſmile,
And laugh to ſee no Wit come, all the while.

div.head: 139. I, Thou, He.
div.l: SElf-Love's the Quarry, at which all Birds flie
From hence the firſt of Perſons, muſt be, I.
You can both flatter, and Back-bite; thus ſee,
He ſtands next, Thou; and Thou, the neareſt mee.

div.head: 140. Ask, and you ſhall Receive.
div.l: WE read in Scripture; Ask, you ſhall Receive:
But 'tis perform'd only to thoſe, who Give.
Give your Acquaintance, firſt; then They'l give you:
No Chinke, no Drink; Nothing is Gratis now.
Give, and it ſhall be Given you.

div.head: 141. Husband, and Wife; Parents, Children.
div.l: HUsband, & Wife, are both one Fleſh; although,
Before the ſacred Union, They were Two.
Father, and Son, were both one Body; yet,
They can't their Horſes, in one Stable ſet.

div.head: 142. Ʋpon Marc the Lawyer.
div.l: YOu plead your own, in your poor Clients Cauſe:
He Bags no Gold; for all's ſeiz'd by your Claws.
To you the Law is certain; Not to him:
He is as ſure to Sink; as you to Swim.

div.head: 143. To his Father.
div.l: BY how much Man, ſurpaſſeth Woman; I,
By being Male, excel the Female Fry.

div.head: 144. The Italian.
div.l: THe Latine like a Lord, commands his Wife;
And forceth her, to lead a Priſoners Life.
This Man, or none; acts Gods curſe o'er again:
O Woman! I will multiply thy Pain.

div.head: 145. What kinde of Wife.
div.l: LEt Vertue, Beauty, be in Her conjoyn'd;
Let her be courted; yet bear a chaſte Minde.
Rivals I like in Love: For I, alone;
Should be a Fool, to Fancy any One.

div.head: 146. To one complaining, that he could Beget no Children, like Himſelf.
div.l: FIrſt get a Wife, in Viſage, much like Thee:
Then draw thy Picture, on Poſteritie.

div.head: 147. To Husbands concerning Conjugal Affection.
div.l: WHen happy Adam, took Eve for his Bride;
He lov'd her more, then the whole world Beſide.
He was the firſt, of Husbands; and the beſt:
To ſerve Eve, in his room; now, Love is preſt.

div.head: 148. The Epitaph of Sir Francis Drake.
div.l: SUppoſe Queen Maries Reign, once more return;
You may reſt certain; Malice, can't you Burn.
You did complot, your Corps from Fire to ſave;
When you elected ſuch a watry Grave.

div.head: 149. An Epitaph, upon a Youth, dying before Father's or Grand-Father.
div.l: DEath's no Logician; not Methodical:
To make young Sons, before old Parents, fall.

div.head: 150. The Epitaph of Maurus.
div.l: THy Soul, doth want a Body; Body, Soul:
You nothing have, but Name: you, want the whole.

div.head: 151. The Epitaph of Pyramus, and Thisbe.
div.l: GRief did contrive your Death, Death like a Friend,
Reveng'd the wrong; and brought Grief to its end.

div.head: 152. Sir Tho. More at his Execution.
div.l: VVHat though Head was, from Body ſevered?
More would not let Body be cut from Head.

div.head: 153. Three Languages were Crucified.
div.l: THe Grecian Tongue, Porter of Wit, and Art:
The Regal Roman: That, God did impart.

div.head: 154. Don Antonio, King of Portugal.
div.l: A Late Divorce, the Kingdom from you rent;
Though to the Bill, you never gave conſent.
You may well ſay (now from the Throne you're hurl'd),
With Chriſt; My Kingdom, is not of this World.

div.head: 155. Alexander, and Ariſtotle.
div.l: THe greateſt King; the man, to wonder, wiſe;
Under their Notions, theſe two Names compriſe.
Great was Macedo; but the Stagyrite,
As much outſhin'd; as bright Day, Cypreſs Night.
The Sages Learning did direct the King:
But the Kings Greatneſs, could no honour bring.

div.head: 156. Plato.
div.l: THoſe Bees, which choſe thy ſweet Mouth for their Hive;
To gather Honey from thy Works, ſurvive.

div.head: 157. Virgil's Georgicks.
div.l: THoſe Verſes, which you ſent, to hold the Plough;
The Readers fallow Wits, both Till, and Sow.

div.head: 158. The Poet Perſius.
div.l: I Read your Satyrs; but can't underſtand:
An Oedipus fetch, Readers! out of hand.

div.head: 159. Tacitus.
div.l: VErtue, made you ſpeake True; Nature, made Wiſe;
Shortneſs, Obſcure; and Gravity, Conciſe.

div.head: 160. To Martial.
div.l: YOu lov'd to ſpeak of Things; but perſons ſpare:
Your Jeſts want Spleen; & ſweet as Hony are.

div.head: 161. To Petrarch.
div.l: WHilſt Laura may be view'd; thy burniſht ſtrains;
Start boundleſs diſputes, in the Gazors Brains;
Whether fair Laura, is more due to Thee;
Or the Proſtration, of the Laurel-Tree.

div.head: 162. Pliny Tranſlated into Engliſh by Doctor Holland.
div.l: PLiny is Long, 'cauſe many things he writes;
Pliny is ſhort, much Matter, He endites.
Holland is Longer; Shorter; becauſe He,
Hath Writ more full; hath ſhun'd Obſcuritie.

div.head: 163. Concerning Cicero. To Catullus.
div.l: NOne could of falſhood, Catullus convict;
Nor that, which he of Tully, did Predict.

div.head: 164. To the Hiſtorians of our Age.
div.l: BEcauſe of old, Hiſtorians would not Lie;
They were rewarded with an Eulogie.
But now He all Competitors outvies;
Whoſe Pen is fertil, with the Rampant Lies.
What one Proteſts, others defie; how can
Poſterity confide, in this; that Man?
No Scioliſt to Blot his Species ſpares:
Scarce any Modern Author, Truth reveres.

div.head: 165. The King. His Subjects.
div.l: A Prince, Imprudent; Subjects will confound;
As the Feet ſtumble, when the Brains are drown'd.

div.head: 166. The Parliament.
div.l: THe King, is King, alone; unto him Sole,
Why not Affairs, committed in the Whole?
Becauſe of Juſtice, this makes him the Fount;
That though he Rules; He muſt give an Account.

div.head: 167. To the Hiſtorian.
div.l: YOu noting Story, without harm, commence.
Expert in Things; which ſad experience,
The Learned taught. What would be long to Try;
Is quickly known from Claſſick Hiſtory.

div.head: 168. Concerning Diet. To J. H.
div.l: IF you would ſhun old Age; be ſure to Uſe,
Moderate Phyſick: or not to abuſe
Your ſelf, with Feaſtings. If you ſhould like Meat,
Take Phyſick; 'tis the way, not long to eat:
But if; as upon Phyſick, you Meals make;
Thin Diet's Healthful: and there's no Miſtake.

div.head: 169. The Peers of France.
div.l: NOt at all Equals! yet ſometimes, we ſee
Unequal Concord; equals diſagree.

div.head: 170. Publius Magnus. Cato Major. Fabius Maximus.
div.l: THe greateſt was leſs, then the Great; yet ſtill,
Made the Greater, under wing keep his Bill.
Now you have read the Riddle, Anſwer Me;
Which was the very Greateſt, of the Three?

div.head: 171. To T. S.
div.l: MY Wit, and judgment, ſerve not to rehearſe,
Thy rare Endowments, in a poliſht verſe.
Your Judgment, Wit; over all Arts prevail:
Unleſs both Wit, and Judgment, in Me fail.
But though my Wit, and Judgment, little be:
Yet I have Judg'd the Truth; concerning Thee.

div.head: 172. Of Himſelf.
div.l: NO wonder that my Epigrams, are Lead:
I never bite my Nails, nor ſcratch my Head.

div.head: 173. The five Senſes.
div.l: DO the five ſervant-Senſes, more aſſiſt
Us, in our Wils, and Pleaſure; or reſiſt?

div.head: 174. Seeing.
div.l: TO pleaſing Objects, Sight, conveys the Minde;
And as her Vaſſal, doth it ſtrongly binde.

div.head: 175. Hearing.
div.l: SWeet Sounds, make in our Ears, but little ſtay;
They come like Air; like Air, they fly away.

div.head: 176. Smelling.
div.l: THe Noſe is plac'd betwixt the Mouth & Eyes:
In Bodies; Spirits; doth Sent exerciſe.

div.head: 177. Taſting.
div.l: THat you may diſguſt nothing, you ſhould Eat:
Let Hunger, give the Hogoo, to your Meat.

div.head: 178. Feeling.
div.l: A Touch may Tickle; or give bare Delight:
The firſt, is young; the laſt, is old Mens Right.

div.head: 179. The Objects of the Senſes.
div.l: THe things I ſee, Hear, Smell, Taſte, Touch; pretence,
Make to affect; but do infect, my Senſe.

div.head: 180. Touch and Taſte.
div.l: SOme are devoid of Smell; ſome Deaf, we finde:
And 'tis no Rarity, to ſee men Blinde.
But with want of Taſte, Touch; the Fates ne'r ſtrike:
By Taſte I live; by Touch, beget my Like.

div.head: 181. An Epigram. A Satyr.
div.l: AN Epigram may aptly ſtiled be,
The long-ledg'd Satyrs, brief Epitomie.
A Satyr bears equal Reſpect; and is
An Epigram, with a Periphraſis.
Satyrs, without their Stings; are hiſs'd by all:
So Epigrams, if not Satyrical.

div.head: 182. Ʋpon one Dumb.
div.l: HE moves his Lips, yet ſpeak I can't him hear:
Fetch Apollonius, for Interpreter.

div.head: 183. The Blinde, and Deaf.
